title: Controlling Anger
introduction: Islam teaches us to control our anger and respond with patience, wisdom, and forgiveness. Anger is a natural emotion, but when left unchecked, it can cause great harm to our relationships, hearts, and deeds. The Prophet ﷺ gave us practical and spiritual guidance to manage anger and transform it into something that pleases Allah.

sections.heading: Dangers of Anger
sections.content: Uncontrolled anger can lead to actions or words that we later regret — hurting others, breaking family ties, or committing sins. The Prophet ﷺ warned that anger is from Shaytan, and it opens the door to evil. Anger clouds our judgment and makes us forget to fear Allah in that moment. Many broken friendships and families can be traced back to harsh words spoken in anger. Recognizing its dangers is the first step to taming it.

sections.heading: How to Control Anger
sections.content: The Prophet ﷺ gave clear advice for controlling anger. When you feel anger rising, seek refuge in Allah by saying *'A'udhu billahi min ash-shaytan ir-rajim'* (I seek refuge with Allah from the accursed devil). Stay silent instead of reacting immediately. If you are standing, sit down; if sitting, lie down — changing your position helps calm the body and mind. Making wudu (ablution) cools the heat of anger. Take deep breaths and reflect before speaking. Regularly remembering Allah and practicing patience helps you build self-control over time.

sections.heading: Virtues of Patience
sections.content: Controlling anger is a sign of true strength and self-mastery. The Prophet ﷺ said, 'The strong person is not the one who can wrestle others, but the one who controls himself when angry.' (Sahih Bukhari) Allah praises those who restrain their anger and forgive others, promising them His love and the reward of Paradise: *'And those who restrain anger and pardon people — and Allah loves the doers of good.'* (Quran 3:134). Each time you hold back anger for Allah’s sake, you gain His pleasure and protection.

conclusion: Practice patience and forgiveness to overcome anger. Remember that real strength lies in controlling yourself when it’s hardest. May Allah help us manage our emotions, heal our hearts, and reward us with peace and His eternal mercy.
